column1: Questions and Answers About PA College & Saint Joseph's
column2: Pennsylvania College of Health Sciences and Saint Joseph’s have reached a definitive agreement to merge in January of 2024. Check back frequently for updates.

column1: Pennsylvania College of Health Sciences & Saint Joseph's University
column2: In January of 2024, Pennsylvania College of Health Sciences will become part of Saint Joseph’s, expanding opportunities for students in Lancaster, Philadelphia & beyond.

column1: Getting Started - PA College of Health Sciences
column2: Make applying for financial aid simple by following the steps below.  Your Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) is your application for federal grants and loans, and if you are a Pennsylvania resident, it also doubles as your application for state grants offered by the Pennsylvania Higher Education Assistance Agency.  Because the FAFSA is […]

column1: Health Sciences Bachelor's Degrees - PA College of Health Sciences
column2: Our Health Sciences Bachelor’s Degrees are perfect for practicing health care professionals looking to further their education and boost their career.

column1: Vascular Sonography Associate Degree - PA College of Health Sciences
column2: Vascular Sonographers use their unique expertise to examine the veins and arteries of patients, making sure their blood is flowing as it should.

column1: Surgical Technology Degree - PA College of Health Sciences
column2: You’ll learn from certified surgical technologists, and at graduation, you’ll have performed at least 120 procedures in real-life settings.

column1: Nuclear Medicine Technology Academic Certificate - PA College of Health Sciences
column2: In this program, you’ll work in a variety of clinical settings to perform diagnostic evaluations and treatment through the use of radiopharmaceuticals.

column1: Radiography Associate Degree - PA College of Health Sciences
column2: Upon completion of the radiography program, you’ll be eligible to and ready to begin your career as an entry-level radiographer.

column1: Medical Laboratory Science Academic Certificate - PA College of Health Sciences
column2: This program trains students for a crucial role in the detection, diagnosis and treatment of disease, and to save lives through tests and analysis.

column1: Respiratory Care Associate Degree - PA College of Health Sciences
column2: In our respiratory care program, you’ll go hands-on from day one, training with experienced professionals in a variety of simulated and real-life settings.

column1: Diagnostic Medical Sonography Degree - PA College of Health Sciences
column2: We provide hands-on learning with a wide range of real-life diagnostic exams and invasive procedures, from obstetrics and gynecology to vascular and trauma.

column1: Master of Science in Nursing- PA College of Health Sciences
column2: Be part of the next generation of nurse practitioners, with the advanced skills you need to provide high-quality health care.

column1: People of PA College: May 2023 Edition - PA College of Health Sciences
column2: We're proud of the ambitions and accomplishments of our students and alumni - learn some of their stories in our monthly feature:

column1: Associate Degree in Nursing - PA College of Health Sciences
column2: PA College has been preparing nurses for more than 115 years. Learn about our program, including the Associate Degree in Nursing requirements, ASN prerequisites, and Associate Degree in Nursing cost.

column1: Cardiovascular Technology Associate Degree - PA College of Health Sciences
column2: With a cardiovascular technologist education, you’ll learn how to perform procedures that keep blood flowing and keep the heart beating. PA College’s cardiovascular technology program prepares you for an exciting career in this growing health care field.

column1: Bachelor of Science in Nursing Bachelor's Degrees - PA College of Health Sciences
column2: PA College offers several bachelor’s degree in nursing options, including the area’s only Three-Year Accelerated BSN and a fully online RN to BSN. Learn more about what makes our approach to bachelor of science in nursing classes unique.

column1: The Student Experience - PA College of Health Sciences
Lehigh University
column2: Lehigh University | A beautiful setting for boundless possibilities.

column1: About
column2: Located in Pennsylvania's beautiful Lehigh Valley, Lehigh is one of the nation's most distinguished private research universities. Through academic rigor, an entrepreneurial mindset and collaborative opportunities we challenge our students to become the leaders of the future.

column1: Lehigh University
column2: Lehigh University | A beautiful setting for boundless possibilities.

column1: Events & Venues
column2: Lehigh University is an exciting place to be—both inside and outside the classroom. We invite members of the Lehigh community and our neighbors throughout the Lehigh Valley to experience all that the university has to offer, whether it's a free lecture, an art exhibit or one of our many athletic events.

column1: Bethlehem & the Lehigh Valley
column2: Located in the heart of the beautiful Lehigh Valley, Bethlehem is a vibrant city, rich in history and known for its small-town friendliness and feel.

column1: Maps & Directions: View Lehigh's Interactive Map
column2: 2018 Redesign: About: Maps & Directions |

column1: Visitors & the Community
column2: About: Visitors & the Community |

column1: University Leadership
column2: Lehigh’s leadership continues to support and advance the university’s important efforts in teaching, research and service.

column1: Lehigh History & Our Founder, Asa Packer
column2: Lehigh University’s founder Asa Packer, the industrial pioneer, entrepreneur and philanthropist laid the foundation for Lehigh University that has since educated generations of students and served as a force of positive societal change.

column1: University Statistics
column2: Recognized among the nation's premier research universities, Lehigh offers a rigorous academic community for nearly 7,000 students. Our small size, ideal student-to-faculty ratio and vibrant campus allow students to collaborate on projects in and out of the classroom.

column1: Coronavirus (COVID-19) Lehigh Information
column2: This website will be updated frequently with important information about the measures Lehigh is taking to support the health and well-being of our community, as well as our neighbors in Bethlehem.

column1: Jobs - Build your career at Lehigh
column2: At Lehigh, staff, faculty, and researchers work together to prepare future generations of leaders in every field. The university’s collaborative environment is just one reason why we ranked as the top midsize employer in education on the Forbes Best Employers list for 2018. Our employees are supported in their career aspirations, community service interests and personal

column1: Diversity, Inclusion & Equity at Lehigh
column2: Lehigh is committed to being an institution that strives to enhance diversity, inclusion and equity. Our ongoing goal is to ensure that all members of our community feel safe, valued and welcome. Share Your Thoughts

column1: Web Site Copyright Notice

column1: Homepage | Lehigh Alumni
column2: Welcome to the official site for Lehigh University Alumni! Discover information regarding involvement, investment, and lifelong connection.

column1: Action & Impact
column2: Strengthen Lehigh, change your world Our recognition societies are one way to celebrate the donors who make great things happen with their generous and committed support. Our community of alumni, families, and friends continues a tradition of generosity, fueling Lehigh's impact in the world. Thank you for making a difference.

column1: Housing & Dining
column2: As part of the Lehigh family, you’ll be immersed in a welcoming and vibrant community where learning and living go hand in hand. We want your time on campus to be rewarding and enjoyable, both inside and outside the classroom.

column1: Clubs & Organizations
column2: Lehigh offers more than 200 student clubs & organizations providing something for everyone. Starting your own club is also an option if you can’t find the perfect fit.

column1: Student Support and Transition to College
column2: Lehigh University students are bright, inquisitive, accomplished, well­-rounded, driven and goal-oriented, but the university experience can present an entirely new set of challenges and expectations, even for the highest-achieving students. We provide numerous student support services in your transition to college, helping each student succeed academically and develop as individuals. As a student, your personal evolution begins as soon as you arrive on campus.

column1: Arts & Athletics at Lehigh
column2: Whether you are interested in participating in Lehigh’s club or Division I athletics scene as a player or a fan, taking advantage of the many on-campus art galleries or exploring your passion for music or theater, Lehigh has something for everyone.

column1: Living at Lehigh
column2: Residence halls are not only where you sleep, study and hang out, but also where the intersection of your education, identity and society begins. Current students who are looking for specific housing details like floor plans, room rates, room assignment information and more, please visit Lehigh Housing Services.

Our students hail from all over the United States, and the world, and represent all walks of life. We value this diversity and recognize the essential role it plays in contributing to rich, vibrant and engaging campus culture.

We are committed to providing a safe living and learning environment that helps each student reach his or her full potential, with a focus on prevention and education.

column1: Introduction to VPNs | Library & Technology Services
column2: What is a VPN? A VPN is a secure connection that can be made between a computer (such as a user's computer at home or on the road) and a protected or private corporate network (such as Lehigh's campus network), using an otherwise insecure public network (such as the Internet). column1: Scientists produce first open source all-atom models of COVID-19 ‘spike’ protein
column2: The virus SARS coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is the known cause of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). The “spike” or S protein facilitates viral entry into host cells. Now a group of researchers from Lehigh University, Seoul National University in South Korea, and the University of Cambridge in the UK have worked together to produce the first open-source all-atom models of a full-length S protein.

column1: Mechanical Engineering & Mechanics
column2: Welcome Mechanical engineering is one of the broadest engineering professions, dealing with the design, construction and operation of various types of machinery. Mechanical engineers manage systems for energy conversion, material transport, and the control of motions and forces. Our vibrant community is filled with exceptional faculty members and motivated students who are working together and with their peers from other disciplines. Please browse our website to learn more about our department, and contact us with questions.

column1: McAndrew, Thomas
column2: Thomas McAndrew is a computational scientist working at the intersection of biostatistics and data science. Dr.McAndrew’s research aims to build more accurate, calibrated computational models of the trajectory of infectious agents by combining data generated by a surveillance system and human judgment such as perceptions/predictions. He received his Ph.D. in Mathematical Sciences from the University of Vermont, an MS in Biostatistics from Georgetown University, and a BS in Biomathematics from the University of Scranton.

column1: Graduate Studies
column2: Overview The Department of Mechanical Engineering and Mechanics offers innovative graduate degree paths at the master's and doctoral levels. All programs can be undertaken on either a full-time or a part-time basis. Masters The Master of Science Degree has four different tracks, which provide the student with opportunities to focus not only on areas of particular interest in mechanical engineering, but also, if desired, to engage in other disciplines of engineering and science, as well as in non-engineering disciplines in other colleges.

column1: Optimizing Remote Direct Memory Access for a faster, more robust internet
column2: We are not a species that likes to wait. Especially when it comes to our online demands—we want instant responses to our queries, and immediate confirmation of our posts.Meeting such expectations requires distributed computing systems capable of meeting demand while still preserving the integrity of the data they are providing. Distributed systems enable resource sharing in the form of hardware, software, or data, and comprise multiple machines connected through a network. The internet is the largest, best known example; others include social networks, online gaming, and e-commerce.

Structural bioinformatics, structural and computational biology.

column1: Adhikarla ’18G recognized with INDIS 2021 Best Paper Award
column2: CSE doctoral student contributed to work on data transfer node optimization while completing Energy Sciences Network internship A team including Eashan Adhikarla ’18G, a PhD student in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering, won the Best Paper Award at the 8th IEEE/ACM International Workshop on Innovating the Network for Data-Intensive Science (INDIS 2021). The workshop was held in conjunction with the 2021 IEEE/ACM International Conference for High Performance Computing, Networking, Storage and Analysis (SC21) in November.

column1: CSE's Chuah delivers 2021 CFK Memorial Lecture to Institution of Engineers, Malaysia
column2: Lehigh University’s Mooi Choo Chuah, a professor of computer science and engineering, was recently invited by the Institution of Engineers, Malaysia (IEM), and the University of Malaya’s Engineering Alumni Association to deliver the 31st Annual Professor Chin Fung Kee Memorial Lecture.Chuah’s lecture, entitled “My Industry to Academia Research Journey and Energizing Innovations among Malaysian Engineers,” shared her research journey from industry to academia, which began in Malaysia and continued in the United States.

column1: Jacob Nelson: Researching Remote Direct Memory Access technology
column2: “My graduate education has probably been the smartest choice I’ve made for myself,” says Jacob Nelson ’17 ’19G. Nelson is a fourth-year PhD student in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering (CSE). His research involves distributed systems and using Remote Direct Memory Access (RDMA) technology to solve problems associated with coordination between multiple actors and processes. In basic terms, distributed systems are those in which networked computers communicate by passing messages. RDMA facilitates this data sharing.

column1: Roberto Palmieri: Getting in synch
column2: Imagine a bank processing your withdrawals before it accepts prior deposits. Or an online store taking 500 orders for an item it has just 25 to sell. The chaos of overdrawn accounts and unfulfilled purchases would seem ridiculous. “Our minds work in a sequential way,” says Roberto Palmieri, an assistant professor of computer science and engineering (CSE).

column1: Sihong Xie: Pulling back the curtain on the intelligence behind AI
column2: If algorithms are going to impact nearly every aspect of our lives, they should meet the highest standards of accountability. Yet little is known—particularly to those outside the field of computer science—about how these algorithms actually operate. Making this form of artificial intelligence more transparent to the lay audience is the driving force behind the work of Lehigh University faculty member Sihong Xie. “Creating accountable machine learning is the ultimate goal of our research,” he says. Xie, an assistant professor of computer science and engineering in the P.C.

column1: $1M NSF grant funds Lehigh cross-disciplinary team converging on pandemic prediction and prevention research
column2: Imagine if researchers could predict the spread of a pandemic like they can the evolution of a hurricane. With the right data, they could help people stay out of harm’s way. Harnessing that ability is the bold vision of a multidisciplinary team of Lehigh researchers. The team recently received a $1 million grant in support of their proposal to examine pandemic dynamics within isolated and underserved populations. The award is part of the National Science Foundation’s new Predictive Intelligence for Pandemic Prevention (PIPP) program, which is jointly funded by NSF’s Directorates for Biological Sciences, Computer Information Science and Engineering, Engineering, and Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences.

column1: Graduate Computer Science Courses
column2: CSE 302 Compiler Design: Principles of artificial language description and design. Sentence parsing techniques, including operator precedence, bounded-context, and syntax-directed recognizer schemes. The semantic problem as it relates to interpreters and compilers. Dynamic storage allocation, table grammars, code optimization, compiler-writing languages.CSE 303 Operating System Design: Process and thread programming models, management, and scheduling. Resource sharing and deadlocks. Memory management, including virtual memory and page replacement strategies.

column1: Sihong Xie: Increasing transparency in machine learning decision-making
column2: In machine learning, “optimization algorithms are becoming more and more important, for two reasons,” says Sihong Xie, an assistant professor of computer science and engineering. “One is that, as the data sets become larger and larger, you cannot process all the data at the same time; and the second reason is that we can formulate an optimization problem that will analyze why the machine learning algorithm makes a particular decision.”

column1: Xie studying the fairness of graphical models
column2: A team of undergraduates from Lehigh, NYU, and the University of San Francisco investigated the fairness of graphical models in machine learning. The team found that the state-of-the-art model, called "graph neural networks", can pick up and exacerbate the bias in graph data for person/business credibility evaluation. The research found that unfair predictions by the graphical model can be caused by the number of connections a node has. The finding agrees with our daily intuition.

column1: Lehigh Blockchain: Return on investment
column2: Chances are—and no judgment!—you don’t know a whole lot about blockchain. But, says professor Hank Korth (pictured), you probably know more about it than many of the lawmakers crafting policies around the digital ledger system. “Our society lacks people who understand what blockchain is and how it works,” says Korth, who is a faculty member in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering (CSE). “And this is technology with a lot of current and potential implications for enterprise, regulation, digital currency, and how businesses relate to each other.

column1: Daley, Sean
column2: Sean M. Daley is an applied sociocultural anthropologist and ethnographer whose research lies primarily at the intersections of religion, spirituality, and health. Much of his work has focused on contemporary American Indian health, wellness, and spirituality. He has also worked in the areas of Native law and policy, identity, education, and the environment. He has been collaborating with Native peoples since 1995 and has worked on projects with Native communities in Arizona, Connecticut, Kansas, Montana, New Mexico, Oklahoma, and South Dakota, as well several other states.

column1: Gómez, Eduardo
column2: Dr. Eduardo J. Gómez is an Associate Professor and Director of the Institute for Health Policy and Politics at Lehigh University. A political scientist by training, his research focuses on the politics of global health policy, with a focus on emerging middle-income countries.

column1: 2023-24 Graduate Loan Application
column2:
Financial aid for Lehigh University’s graduate programs consists mainly of fixed-rate federal student loans through the Office of Financial Aid. Students must be enrolled in a degree-seeking program and be registered at least half-time to be eligible for federal loans (6 credits each semester during the academic year, or 3 credits for each summer session). 

A Free Application for Federal Student Aid must be filed in order to apply for federal student loans and Graduate students may be eligible to borrow up to $20,500 through this Unsubsidized loan program.  If additional funding is needed, a student can apply for a Federal Direct Graduate PLUS Loan or a private education loan, both of which require a separate application process.  Information on that process can be found on our website.  For information regarding assistantships, fellowships, or other forms of scholarships and financial aid, please contact the department or college in which you are enrolled.  

If you have not yet borrowed through the Direct Loan Program, you will be required to complete a new Master Promissory Note (MPN) and complete the Entrance Counseling Session. If you previously borrowed through the Direct Loan Program and signed the Master Promissory Note less than 10 years ago, you will only be required to complete the Entrance Counseling Session for the first year in which you borrow at the graduate level.

column1: Industrial and Systems Engineering
column2: Industrial and Systems Engineering is the engineering of decision-making. Our tools can be applied throughout business, science, engineering, and beyond, in both the private and public sectors. Industrial and systems engineers design, improve, and optimize processes, systems, and products and services themselves. In today’s competitive marketplace in which cost efficiency and scarcity of resources are paramount, industrial and systems engineers play a critical role. This is why our graduates are so sought-after.

column1: 2023 Lehigh Rossin College and ISE Awards
column2: On Thursday, May 4, 2023, the ISE Department held its annual Awards Ceremony in Mohler Laboratory. It is our pleasure to announce and celebrate the achievements of our alumni, faculty, staff, and students. The first award below was given by the Rossin College on May 8. 2023 Rossin Excellence in Research Scholarship & Leadership Award Professor Frank E. Curtis has won the 2023 P.C. Rossin College of Engineering and Applied Science Excellence in Research Scholarship & Leadership Award.

column1: Lehigh ISE Chair has been elected Chair of Optimization at SIAM
column2: Luis Nunes Vicente has been elected Chair of the SIAM Activity Group on Optimization for the upcoming 2023-2025 term. Luis is currently the Timothy J. Wilmott Endowed Chair Professor and Chair of the Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering at Lehigh University. The Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics (SIAM) is the largest and most prestigious applied math society. Among its many research activity groups, the Optimization one (SIAG/Optimization) was one of the very first groups and is one of the largest, counting with more than 1,000 researchers from academia and industry.

column1: Four Lehigh University Faculty Awards have been given to ISE faculty
column2: We are extremely pleased to announce that four Lehigh faculty have won 2023 Lehigh University Faculty Awards: Prof. Curtis (Libsch Research Award), Prof. Shehadeh (Alfred Noble Robinson Faculty), Prof. Snyder (Christian & Mary Lindback Award for Distinguished Teaching), and Prof. Terlaky (Hillman Faculty). Professor Frank E. Curtis has won the 2023 Lehigh University Libsch Research Award. This is one of the most prestigious senior faculty awards at Lehigh. Prof. Curtis fully deserves to be among those distinguished past awardees, some of the finest researchers Lehigh has ever had.

column1: SIAM’s Prestigious Summer School awarded to Lehigh for Quantum Computing and Optimization
column2: The prestigious Gene Golub SIAM Summer School (G2S3) program was founded by Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics (SIAM) as a result of a generous bequest of former SIAM president Gene Golub. Once a year, the G2S3 program offers a graduate level summer school in an area of applied mathematics, computational science, and/or industrial mathematics. The 2023 G2S3 was awarded to Lehigh’s Quantum Computing and Optimization Laboratory (QCOL) team with the theme “Quantum Computing and Optimization”.

column1: Air Force Office of Scientific Research awarded nearly $1M to Lehigh ISE
column2: The Mathematical Optimization Program of the Air Force Office of Scientific Research (AFOSR) has recently awarded two grants to Lehigh ISE in a total close to $1M. Lehigh ISE Assistant Professor Aida Khajavirad was awarded a three-year AFOSR $389K grant as the Principal Investigator (PI). The project is called “Novel Optimization Algorithms for Data Science Applications” and will be developed in collaboration with Professor Antonio De Rosa, from the University of Maryland.

column1: Data Science
column2: Lehigh's M.S., Data Science, allows students from a wide range of backgrounds to gain the qualifications necessary to tap into the wealth of data science jobs, many of which require an advanced degree. The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics projects jobs in the field to grow more than 30 percent between 2020 and 2030. Lehigh's Data Science program provides access to the skills and tools of data science to people who want to develop that skillset, even if they don't have a background in computer science or statistics.

column2: CSE doctoral student Zhiyu Chen will apply the specialized skills he developed at Lehigh when he joins Amazon’s Alexa Shopping team after graduation

column1: Nader Motee: Making robots more perceptive
column2: Robots are complex machines with lots of components. Each of these components has a precise purpose, and when each component acts as expected, it creates a seamless system that can accomplish intricate tasks. This idea scales to networks of robots working in tandem to accomplish even more complex tasks. In this case, when one machine falters or fails to collaborate with the others, it can cause chaos: Picture a drone flying away from its fleet and failing to photograph its assigned area, or a self-driving car getting too close to another and disrupting carefully designed platoon.

column1: Tamás Terlaky elected into Canadian Academy of Engineering
column2: Tamás Terlaky, George N. and Soteria Kledaras ’87 Endowed Chair Professor, Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering of Lehigh University, has been elected to The Canadian Academy of Engineering (CAE). The election was announced on June 15, 2020. The Induction Ceremony, will be held in Halifax, Nova Scotia in June 2021.Professor Terlaky is a leading optimization expert with four authored books and over 180 scientific papers. He is Founding Editor-in-Chief of the journal Optimization and Engineering.

column2: The Healthcare Systems Engineering Master Program uses systems modeling and analytics tools coupled with a broad overview of systems of healthcare to enable students to address complex operational challenges. Students will encounter a variety of tools, including: project management, engineering economics, statistics and stochastic modeling, operations research and optimization, process flow and queuing, simulation and information systems analysis and design.

column1: Electrical & Computer Engineering
column2: Greetings from the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering (ECE) at Lehigh University! If you are a dreamer and leader who seeks the challenge of a rigorous engineering education that dissolves the boundaries between traditional disciplines and modes of learning, ours is the environment for you. Lehigh ECE is one of the first universities in the world to offer a degree in electrical engineering, and throughout our proud history we have led the evolution and transformation of our discipline.

column1: A laser breakthrough
column2: The ability to harness light into an intense beam of monochromatic radiation in a laser has revolutionized the way we live and work for more than fifty years. Among its many applications are ultrafast and high-capacity data communications, manufacturing, surgery, barcode scanners, printers, self-driving technology and spectacular laser light displays.

column1: Growing computers in petri dishes
column2: NSF supports Lehigh interdisciplinary research effort to engineer a living neural networkWill the computers of tomorrow be manufactured, or will they be cultivated?This question lies at the heart of new research from Lehigh University that aims to engineer a neural network—a computer system modeled on the human brain and nervous system—from actual living cells, and program it to compute a basic learning task.The National Science Foundation (NSF) has recently announced its support for the project, to the tune of more than $500,000, as part of a wider NSF effort, announced September 11, in suppo

column1: A Sharper Focus on Catastrophe Modeling
column2: Paolo Bocchini, Daniel Conus, Brian Davison and their colleagues leverage their collaborative experience in probabilistic modeling to sharpen their focus on catastrophe modeling, a discipline not traditionally explored in academia.

column1: NHERI Lehigh expands cyber-physical testing capabilities
column2: Lehigh’s NSF-funded Natural Hazards Engineering Research Infrastructure Experimental Facility (NHERI Lehigh EF) has unveiled additional lab space and new equipment for conducting real-time cyber-physical experiments, which are ideal for testing large-scale structural systems that are impractical—or impossible—to test in a normal laboratory. The enlarged facility can accommodate more users and a broader range of hybrid simulation applications for natural hazards researchers to explore structural mitigation solutions for windstorms and earthquakes.

column1: On Solid Ground
column2: By Amanda AllekotteEquipping buildings in earthquake-prone areas with floor-isolation systems (FISs) could protect the people and property housed inside—and help ensure a quicker, less costly recovery.The systems, which decouple the motion of the floor from the response of objects during an earthquake, would enhance the resilience of essential facilities, such as hospitals or power plants, by protecting sensitive, critical equipment, says P. Scott Harvey, an associate professor of civil engineering and environmental science at the University of Oklahoma.

column1: Advancing Critical Infrastructure
column2: Interdisciplinary teams of Lehigh researchers improve key infrastructure using big data from cyberphysical systems.

column1: How Do Powerful Winds Affect Tall Buildings?
column2: Lehigh researchers co-organize and host a collaborative workshop to demonstrate advancements in hybrid simulation to investigate how high winds impact the structural integrity of a 40-story building.

column1: Chemical & Biomolecular Engineering
column2: MISSION To educate students in the scientific principles of chemical and biomolecular engineering and provide opportunities to explore their applications in the context of a humanistic education that prepares them to address technological and societal challenges. PROGRAMS Our undergraduate and graduate academic programs in chemical and biomolecular engineering prepares students for careers in industry, academia, medicine, law, and finance.

column1: Materials Science & Engineering
column2: Welcome to the Department of Materials Science and Engineering, part of the P.C. Rossin College of Engineering and Applied Science at Lehigh University. Accredited since 1936, the department offers one of the nation's leading materials science and engineering programs. Students work closely with award-winning professors who are at the top of their fields in a program that provides an excellent balance between theoretical and practical knowledge. | MORE >>

column1: Partnering to advance research in materials and devices
column2: Lehigh has partnered with Brookhaven National Laboratory, the first of its kind between NSLS-II and an academic research institutionThe National Synchrotron Light Source (NSLS-II), located within the Brookhaven National Laboratory in New York, is one of the world's most advanced synchrotrons.

column1: A material without limits
column2: Cheaper production of an unsung industrial substance could make hard stuff a lot easierBoron nitride has a tough reputation.In its cubic crystal structure, cubic boron nitride, or c-BN, is one of the most remarkably-durable human-made materials ever invented, almost on par with natural and synthetic diamonds.

column1: Flipping a switch in the space between atoms
column2: NSF CAREER Award supports Lehigh professor Nick Strandwitz’s vision of the transistor of the futureThe modern electronic device is made up of an impossibly large number of imperceptibly small parts. A laptop computer, for instance, may have 1.5 billion transistors or switches, says Dr.

column1: Stephen P. DeWeerth
column2: Dr. Stephen P. DeWeerth serves as Dean of the P.C. Rossin College of Engineering and Applied Science and as a professor in the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering at Lehigh University.Prior to his arrival at Lehigh, DeWeerth was a professor in the Wallace H. Coulter Department of Biomedical Engineering at Georgia Tech and Emory University. He also served as professor in Georgia Tech's School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, and as Associate Dean for Research and Innovation for its College of Engineering.DeWeerth received his Ph.D.

column1: CSB student named 2022 Schwarzman Scholar
column2: Will Peracchio ’21 has been selected as a 2022 Schwarzman Scholar. The prestigious graduate fellowship, which was launched in 2015, was inspired by the Rhodes Scholarship at Oxford and designed to prepare future global leaders to meet the geopolitical challenges of the 21st century. Peracchio is pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Computer Science and Business at Lehigh, with minors in data science, economics, and entrepreneurship, and a certificate in global citizenship. In tandem with his undergraduate studies, he is completing a Master of Science in computer science.

column1: CSB Tracks
column2: Students may choose to use their CSB professional electives to develop areas of concentrations. It is not required that a student complete a track, just that students fulfill the 9-credit professional elective requirement. Not all of these courses are offered on a regular basis.

column1: Undergraduate Studies
column2: A detailed description of the curricular programs follows with a listing of the required courses and with a listing of the departmental course offerings. This unofficial listing provided to help in planning, but students should remember that the actual program you should follow is defined in the catalog that was effect when you started at Lehigh. You can also consult Lehigh University Catalog. Each year there are changes to the program and not all of them are necessarily reflected in this web site or the current catalog.

column1: CSB B.S. Degree Requirements
column2: ABET Accreditation Diagram of Courses and Prerequisites The CSB Program is offered jointly by the College of Business and Economics (CBE) and the department of Computer Science and Engineering (CSE). Unlike other programs where students have a dominant college, the CSB program is so balanced that the students are simultaneously in both the College of Business and Economics and the P.C. Rossin College of Engineering and Applied Science (RCEAS).

column1: Healthcare Systems Engineering
column2: "Systems that work do not just happen - they have to be planned, designed and built." -UK Royal Academy of Engineering Our students believe that tomorrow's clinical, administrative and public health leaders need systems engineering methodologies to tackle the complex challenges of healthcare. Lehigh's Health Systems Engineering program gives them the tools to take on these challenges and succeed.

column1: HSE: Department and Program Rankings
column2: The HSE Program resides within the Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering (ISE). One of the nation's earliest systems engineering programs, Lehigh's ISE department, offers several opportunities to pursue degrees that prepare students for employment and/or further advanced study. HSE is proud to be part this prestigious department along with these other graduate programs:M.S./M.Eng. in Industrial and Systems EngineeringM.S./M.Eng in Management Science and EngineeringM.Eng. in Healthcare Systems EngineeringM.S. in Analytical Finance U.S.

column1: HSE Professional Development
column2: Engage, Learn, GrowLehigh's HSE program offers professional development resources to help students in today's business climate. Faculty and mentors provide the tools you will need to succeed in your new role or advance in your present career. Along with the formal coursework, you will have the opportunity further your business and leadership knowledge through various events. Networking with Industry Council members and successful alumni.Attending conferences: Students attend the Healthcare System Process Improvement Conference, sponsored by the Society for Health Systems.

column1: Working Professionals
column2: Healthcare Systems Engineering for the Working ProfessionalMore and more working professionals in the healthcare industry are recognizing the value of earning a graduate degree in order to expand and enhance their skill sets and ultimately reach their next level of career advancement.

column1: The Emerging and Critical Role of Healthcare Systems Engineering in the Pharmaceutical Industry
column2: By Marc Deluca and Jeff Fetterman

column1: Format and Timeline
column2: Two questions that come up frequently are "Can I do this program online?" and "How long does the program take to complete?". Students have the option to complete each course in the program either on campus or online, and students may finish the entire degree online. Oftentime, our students who also work full-time may mix the two modes, i.e. come to campus for some classes, and take the rest online.

column1: Where HSE Alumni Work
column2: Our graduates possess the technical skills necessary to analyze healthcare systems, identify inefficiencies and propose solutions or new processes to improve the overall quality and efficiency of healthcare. Scroll down to see some of our alumni and their positions.

column1: Charting an optimal path
column2: Healthcare Systems Engineering professional master’s alum Michael Kimball ’13 M.Eng. helps hospitals model data to increase efficiency and provide better careWhen St. Luke’s University Health Network wanted to review the productivity of their emergency departments, they turned to Michael Kimball. Kimball, a graduate of Lehigh University’s Healthcare Systems Engineering (HSE) professional master’s program, and his team built a computer simulation model that looked at patient flow for every hour, every day of the week, including level of care required.

column1: In Memoriam: Vincent G. Grassi, ChBE professor of practice
column2: Vincent G. Grassi, a professor of practice in the Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering in the P.C. Rossin College of Engineering and Applied Science, passed away May 3 in The Villages, Fla., from esophageal cancer. He was 64.Grassi, a much-loved instructor, taught courses in all four years of chemical engineering education, freshman through senior year. He was the 2019 recipient of Lehigh’s Donald B. and Dorothy L.

column1: Dr. Vincent Grassi, Professor of Practice in Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, passes away
column2: Dr. Vincent Grassi, Professor of Practice in the Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering passed away on May 3, 2020 in Florida, surrounded by his family after a protracted battle with oesophageal cancer. He was 64 years old and is survived by his wife and daughter. Dr. Grassi received his BS (1978) from the U. of Rochester and MS (1985) and PhD (1991) degrees from Lehigh University, all in Chemical Engineering. He was employed with Air Products & Chemical Inc.

column1: Memories of the late Prof. Vince Grassi
column2: The Lehigh Engineering community mourns the loss of Vincent G. Grassi, a professor of practice in the Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering. Professor Grassi passed away May 3, 2020, from cancer at the age of 64. He was beloved by his students and received the university's Donald B. and Dorothy L. Stabler Award for Excellence in Teaching in 2019. The Chemical Engineering Class of 2020 shared the following remembrances of Professor Grassi during a virtual memorial.

column1: Hughes, John
column2: Dr. Hughes' methodological research focuses on models for dependent data (especially high-dimensional data such as spatial and spatiotemporal data), statistical computing, and Bayesian methods. His interdisciplinary collaborations have spanned several fields, including environmental and occupational health, bioimaging, magnetic-resonance safety, the spatial epidemiology of HPV-related cancers, and vaccine hesitancy. Dr. Hughes has developed many software packages for both R and Perl. For more information, visit Dr. Hughes' website.

column1: Jeff Heflin
column2: Jeff Heflin is an associate professor in the Department of Computer Science and Engineering at Lehigh University. His research interests include the Semantic Web, ontologies, and intelligent agents. He is co-developer of SHOE (one of the first Semantic Web languages), a member of the committee that developed the DAML+OIL language, and was an invited expert to the W3C working group that developed the OWL Web Ontology language.

column1: Data Science
column2: Lehigh's M.S., Data Science, allows students from a wide range of backgrounds to gain the qualifications necessary to tap into the wealth of data science jobs, many of which require an advanced degree. The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics projects jobs in the field to grow more than 30 percent between 2020 and 2030. Lehigh's Data Science program provides access to the skills and tools of data science to people who want to develop that skillset, even if they don't have a background in computer science or statistics.
